comment_text: I think I made a mistake with my calculations and I didn't actually use NaCl in excess. At 100g NaCl, the dichromate is actually the limiting reagent and this definitely cut into my yield. I was basing my prep on my last chromyl chloride video and I think I just propagated that error forward. I should've used at least 130g NaCl instead, and if i were to do this again, I'd probably use like 150-160g.

As a PhD chemist, I do find these videos quite interesting. I also find them quite disturbing. Having had enough close calls in my own life, I've grown to respect chemicals a bit more. While experimentation is absolutely necessary for learning and the advancement of science, "playing" with chemicals isn't the way to do this. Furthermore, I see this producing a lot of toxic materials, which.. again... relatively small scale, so it could be worse. Still, even the idea of sending all those chromium laden fumes up through the hood and out into the atmosphere feels really irresponsible. Oh, and small tip... as you could see at 8:38, using sulfuric acid to seal the glass joint is not effective. Try purchasing some PTFE Glindmann sealing rings in the future. They're inexpensive, they make a vacuum tight seal, and they ensure your glass joint won't fuse. Being PTFE, they're pretty inert, and they don't leave everything greasy like vacuum grease does. They also make a MUCH more robust seal when compared to PTFE sealing SLEEVES which really don't work well at all.

Oh... and don't go smelling benzaldehyde. It should smell like almonds, not cherries... But anyway, you don't want to go burning out your sense of smell and end up with some rare form of nasal cancer in 20 years. (Benzaldehyde may not be carcinogenic, but the toluene and other biproducts are.. and personally I'm more worried about organometallics that you might be forming.)

I know this is an old video and someone may have said it but in case it hasn't been, I suggest you to put Potassium Dichromate on the top of the Sodium Chloride according to the description at 5:14. The reason is that Hydrogen Chloride is the gas. If you put the Potassium Dichromate, which becomes Chromium Trioxide, on the Sodium Chloride, the HCl gas must to go through the Chromium Trioxide layer to escape. If you just mix them, the HCl gas may just escape without touching too many Chromium Trioxide. Just think about some guards trying to prevent some people escape a room. Is it a good idea to mix with these people and catch them when they try to escape, or all the guards just block the exit door so anyone who tries to escape must pass through all of them which is much harder?

One time when I was a kid I was mixing a bunch of chemicals.  One was sulfuric acid, I forget what the others were.  It started to bubble over the side in a green foam. We were headed to Cedar Point and we had to delay the trip to clean the walls.  Although now I work in IT, for 2 years as an adult I worked at a chemical treatment plant.  I worked a lot with HCL, Sulfuric and Phosphoric acid just to name a few.  It really is interesting.

Some also believe that iodide turns brined foods faintly blue (especially poultry) and softens pickled vegetables like cucumbers and carrots, but I'm not sure of that. This video is extremely interesting when one looks at the surface properties of the chemicals used in each experiment. I think the reaction with water probably was a combination from a hydrophobic surface which was occasionally broken by H2O, in particular at the line where the chromyl chloride, air and water are all into contact with eachother. This breakup allowed the water to increase its surface area, accelerating the reaction with the rest of the chromyl chloride. However, the surface of the chromyl chloride drops remains intact next to the break-up points, and that's why you see this 'growing tree' effect on the water surface. It reminds me of fractals.

The toluene reaction shows a lot of effects which are interesting as well.

The chromyl chloride probably creeps up the glass as it's surface at the glass-air-chromyl interface is cut up by moisture in the air. If you happen to do this again, it would be interesting to see how it behaves when in contasct with water vapour or spray.

Guláš je původně maďarský pokrm tvořený nakrájenými masovými kostkami v omáčce z cibule, kořeněné paprikou. Slovo je odvozeno z maďarského „gulya“ (stádo hovězího dobytka), ze kterého pochází maďarský název gulyás (výslovnost [gujáš]) a z toho dále české guláš. V původní maďarské verzi jde o hovězí (jak název napovídá) polévku. Častou přísadou v ní je mrkev a malé bílé knedlíčky zvané csipetke. V maďarské verzi není nikdy zahušťován moukou. Gulyás ač má blízko k polévce, může být i hlavním jídlem, a v maďarštině není výrazného rozdílu mezi gulyás (guláš) a gulyásleves (gulášová polévka). Nejde nutně o krmi ostře kořeněnou, většina papriky v prášku obsažená v guláši je paprika sladká, chceme-li získat verzi pikantní (pálivou), můžeme při podávání talíře či misky polévky dodat kousky čerstvé pálivé papriky anebo přidat rozmačkanou konzervovanou pálivou papriku (např. Erős Pista). Gulyás je vždy podáván s bílým chlebem.
Mimo Maďarsko se pod pojmem guláš rozumí dušené maso následně zahuštěné, podávané se všemožnými přílohami. Tato krmě není identická, ale blíží se maďarskému pörköltu. V angličtině by odpovídal přibližně termín „stew“.

My favorite compound is H 2FSbF6 (Fluroantimonic acid.) It's created by mixing hydrogen fluoride with antimony pentafluoride in a 2:1 ratio.


It's classified as one of the strongest super acids. It's highly toxic, corrosive and reactive. It readily explodes when it comes into contact with any amount of water, destroys any known organic matter and dissolves glass. It also likes to decompose back into its constituent parts if you get it too hot or too cold. The only known safe method to store it is in a PTFE lined vessel.

Before I dare ask you make some substance or solution, I am just gonna say that I take great pleasure in your videos and I find them quite informative and educational. And that comes from someone who does not, I repeat, does not know absolutely anything about chemistry.
That being said, please make some carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC)! From what i have read so far, it is a product used to burnish leather edges, apparently largely produced and used in China, but it is becoming more and more popular in the western countries as well because it is easy to produce (apparently) and it has a very good volume-for-use/yield ratio. Its sodium variant is also used in food products as thickener.
Since I know you like to make some research before you dive into a project, I made things a little easier for you and found some papers and articles on CMC that you might find usefull. Here they are:
1) https://patents.google.com/patent/US3375245A/en
2) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carboxymethyl_cellulose

Excellent videography, as usual. It's good to see properties of more dangerous compounds, and details about how they behave when being handled. Very useful for people who deal with them, even in professional laboratories. Chromyl chloride is one of those things that should really be scrubbed by a reducer when sucked from a fume hood, if the apparatus is available.


However, I simply must say again, because I see no progress, that your form of presentation has certain things that are so repetitive that myself, and several people I'm in daily contact with that watch your stuff, find them increasingly irritating.


Examples:


- you overuse the word though - it is not ok to use it 40-50 times in a 20 minute video, man. It really isn't. If you feel something similar is needed (and often it really isn't), you can start the sentence with "although" or "however". You can join sentences with "but". Being relentlessly thumped with "though" every thirty seconds on average is really annoying, especially when you use it as a filler word where it has zero useful meaning. Couple of us actually counted this once for gruesome fun.


- wrong usage of units - something is not at "ten C". C is nothing. At best, incorrectly said coulomb, unit of charge. Celsius is unit of temperature. It's not difficult to pronounce it. Correct would be "degrees Celsius", as those really are degrees and not just simple unit like kelvin, but plain "Celsius" is just fine.
Other unit you constantly pronounce wrong is ml. It's not "mils". Mils are thousands of an inch. Just because some lazy people can't say millilitre doesn't mean it's nice to constantly hear it from a chemistry youtuber. Related to this, it's "separatory funnel", not "sep funnel". Keep it professional.


- pleonasms - "sodium metal", "oxygen gas", are not names of chemical substances . At best, they are names for chemical and physical states, but in that case it's always better to say "elemental sodium/oxygen". In case of just talking about elements , their names are sodium and oxygen. You don't see "bromine liquid" in the periodic table of elements.
Sarin is not a gas, it's liquid, but when talking about it in general, it's sarin, not "sarin gas".
This is something that has become rampant on Youtube, spread by American chemistry youtubers and even copied by others that use English who don't have formal education. It's truly a meme.


- nitpicking - there is no need to explain every single detail of what's happening on the screen. If you place down a beaker, you don't need to say it. You describe nearly every action that happens on the screen. It comes off as OCD, it increases the amount of words you have to say, cramming the speech and forcing you to speak faster to be able to make a short enough video. Add "though" to it and it becomes information noise.


- style of speaking - Your videos are identical blocks of speech with predictable speech patterns: intonation, speed, melody, tone, rhythm, stress. It doesn't engage the viewer. It lulls them. Make a pause now and then. Ask the viewer a question. Insert a smart pun. Create a small tangent. Anything to break apart the monotony.


Please don't take this as rude mocking. Take this as useful criticism. Remember that I wouldn't bother if your channel was stupid and had nothing to offer. I, and many others, do not skip through your videos and then post a cringy "popular format" comment just to get thumbs up in order to validate ourselves. Just look at the top ones - stupid stuff that completely ignores the content. We sit and watch it through because you have genuinely interesting content. It is difficult to sit through it when the brain starts to focus on these repetitive, annoying details.
You have a lot more to offer.

where do the fumes go after they are captured in the fume hood?

I know the fume hood will extract it from your workspace, and protect you, but where does the fume hood dump the fumes?

I'm concerned about the possibility that you may be depositing toxic fumes and dust into the immediate environment around your house... is there a capture mechanism in the exhaust of your fume hood that can prevent you accidentally dusting your garden or driveway with carcinogenic waste? First of all nice synthesis. I realy enjoyed you showing all the differnt behaviours of the compound.
However one thing stuck out to me: you are storing your chromyl chloride in a seald ampule together with cardboard paper in a sealed lid jar.
In a potential scenario the ampule could leak, its content react with the cardboard, produce gas, which can not escape the jar.
That's a bomb-which, when it explodes will spread chromyl chloride everywhere and is a giant fire hazard.
I recomend using glaswool ore NaCl as an inert storing material.
Ceep up the good work.

My uncle once told me about an incident at the hospital he was working at. The hospital was old and was going to shut down and make room for a new building that would be better able to help people. So, he and several others had to help clear out a lot of the old items they had in storage. Entire encyclopedias from 50+ years ago covered in dust. Old phonographs with recordings on their wax cylinders as well as blank ones. One old doctor had an old desk with some of his old things in it. This desk had a copy of Mein Kampf (written by Adolf Hitler). What shocked everyone was an old wooden crate with some bottles in it. It had been left there for decades and nobody knew what was in it. One of the guys picked up the bottle and turned white as a ghost and said: "...oh...shit...nobody move."


Turns out someone left this small crate there and forgot about it. The problem was that it was nitroglycerine...and it was very old. For those who don't know, nitroglycerine (in its pure liquid form) is a contact explosive. Shaking the bottle could cause it to combust and explode. What's bad is that as it degrades, it becomes even more unstable. So here, they had bottles of it in an old wooden box that had been stored there for decades. Needless to say, they had to evacuate the building and get the bomb squad to dispose of the nitroglycerine.


Sometime after that, I helped him and some other guys clear out a lot of the old junk they had inside. Lots of very old books got thrown into the dump. I felt for sure someone would have loved to have gone through all those old medical books.

That is some FASCINATING behavior to me, a total non-chemist but computer scientist/software engineer.  When it rapidly diffuses and disappears in the water, it looks like some 3D cellular automata I have seen or maybe a very fast reaction-diffusion system (which I suppose would make the most sense, though I haven't seen one that looks quite like the fringey bursts seen in this video, I have played with an awful lot more CA than R-D systems too).  The 'dancing' up and down also just looks cool, to see those dynamics playing out on such a human timescale.  So much of chemistry is either too fast or too slow for humans to really appreciate from a realtime video, but that 'dancing' is perfect! Just something I wanted to add:

It's definitely a bit dangerous but you COULD increase the efficiency of this rxn by making pure CrO3 by SLOWLY adding sulfuric acid to potassium dichromate and then filtering on a glass fritted funnel and washing with 65% nitric acid. Then you could weigh the dry powder and react dry HCl with the red powder to quantitatively make the chromyl chloride.

Obviously this is dealing with even MORE corrosive acids and waste but there is a way to get FABULOUS yield if you really want to.
